questions.text: Which of the following risk factors is associated with both gallbladder cancer and cholangiocarcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC)

Explanation:

Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), particularly when associated with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), is a major risk factor for both gallbladder cancer and cholangiocarcinoma.

Aspect

Gallbladder Cancer

Cholangiocarcinoma

Risk Factors

Gallstones, porcelain gallbladder, PSC, abnormal pancreatic-biliary junction

PSC, congenital cystic disease, hepatolithiasis, liver flukes

Clinical Presentation

Abdominal pain, early satiety, anorexia, weight loss, jaundice, Courvoisier's sign

Similar non-specific symptoms, jaundice, Courvoisier's sign

Diagnosis

USG, CT, MRI/MRCP, elevated ALT, AST, CA19-9, and ERCP/PTC, staging laparoscopy

Similar diagnostic tools and markers

Treatment

Radical en bloc resection for resectable cases

Hepatic/bile duct resection, pancreaticoduodenectomy, transplantation for select cases

Prognosis

Poor, low 5-year survival rate

Poor, low 5-year survival rate

Gallstones (Option A) are strongly associated with gallbladder cancer, while the relationship with cholangiocarcinoma is less clear.

Porcelain gallbladder (Option B) is a risk factor for gallbladder cancer only

Hepatitis C virus infection (Option D) is a risk factor primarily for cholangiocarcinoma.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presents with severe right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, and a history of recurrent cholangitis. Imaging reveals a cholecystocholedochal fistula involving up to two-thirds of the circumference of the common bile duct. Which type of Mirizzi syndrome is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Type III

 

Explanation:

In this scenario, the imaging findings indicate that the fistula involves up to two-thirds of the circumference of the CBD, consistent with Type III Mirizzi syndrome

 

Mirizzi’s syndrome
It is seen in 1% of all cholecystectomies where a gallstone impacts the gallbladder wall, leading to compression and pressure necrosis. This often results in adherence to the common hepatic duct (CHD) or common bile duct (CBD) wall and can occasionally lead to a cholecystocholedochal fistula.

 

Csendes Classification :

 

Mirizzi’s Type

Features

Image

Type I

Extrinsic compression of the CBD/CHD by a large impacted stone in Hartmann's pouch;

  • IA- the presence of cystic duct
  • IB- is obliterated cystic duct

Type II

The stone has eroded the CBD/CHD less than 1/3rd circumference of the CBD/CHD forming a fistula

Type III

Involving up to 2/3rd of the circumference of CBD/ CHD

Type IV

Cholecystocholedochal fistula (>2/3rd) involving the entire circumference of the CBD/CHD

TypeV

Cholecystocholedochal fistula with cholecystoenteric fistula without gallstone ileus (VA) or with

gallstone ileus (VB)

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presents with right upper quadrant pain and nausea. An ultrasound reveals a 1.5 cm gallbladder polyp, and a follow-up scan shows an increase in size from the previous scan six months ago. She also has a history of gallstones. Which of the following factors increases the risk of invasive cancer in gallbladder polyps?

choices.text: The same polyp size on repeated scans

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Presence of gallstones

 

Explanation:
The presence of gallstones increases the risk of malignancy

 

Ultrasonography demonstrating a gallbladder polyp

 

Cholesterol polyp

Adenomatous polyp
  • More common
  • Small <10 mm
  • Multiple
  • Benign
  • Pedunculated
  • Less common
  • Large >10mm
  • Single
  • Premalignant
  • Sessile

Factors that increase the risk of invasive cancer in adenomatous polyp:

  • Age more than 60 years (Option A)
  • Presence of gallstone
  • Size of polyp more than 1 cm (Option C)
  • Documented increase in size on repeated scans (Option D)

Treatment:

  • Cholecystectomy is recommended for symptomatic patients or as a preventive measure to reduce the risk of cancer in individuals who have additional conditions like gallstones, primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), biliary colic, or pancreatitis.
  • Polyps in patients over 50, sessile polyps with wall thickening exceeding 4 mm, and those larger than 10 mm warrant surgical removal. Smaller polyps should be monitored, with surgery indicated if there is evidence of growth.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male in the ICU with sepsis and multiple organ failure develops sudden right upper quadrant pain and fever. Ultrasound reveals a distended gallbladder with thickened walls and no gallstones. Which of the following is not a predisposing factor for acalculous cholecystitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hypertension

 

Explanation:

Hypertension is not an established predisposing factor for acalculous cholecystitis

 

Acalculous cholecystitis

Acalculous cholecystitis is an acute inflammation of the gallbladder that occurs without the presence of gallstones. It is typically observed in critically ill patients or in patients who have undergone major surgeries, trauma, burns, or prolonged illness with multi-system failure.

 

Causes:

  • Gallbladder distention
  • Bile stasis
  • Ischemia
  • Cystic artery occlusion
  • Primary bacterial infections (e.g., E. coli, Salmonella, Clostridia) may contribute.

Predisposing Factors:

  • Critically ill ICU patients
  • Patients on parenteral nutrition (Option A)
  • Extensive burns (Option B)
  • Sepsis
  • Major surgeries (especially non-biliary)
  • Multiple trauma
  • Prolonged illness with multiple organ system failure
  • Elderly males
  • Diabetic patients (Option D)
  • Patients on atherosclerotic agents.
  • Patients with AIDS
  • Presence of malignancies (biliary or other)

questions.text: A 75-year-old female with a history of cholelithiasis presents with acute abdominal pain, vomiting, and signs of bowel obstruction. O/E, she has abdominal distension and high-pitched bowel sounds. A radiograph shows pneumobilia and a calcified gallstone in the right lower quadrant. CT confirms an abnormal gallbladder with air and fluid accumulation. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Conservative management with IV fluids and antibiotics

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Enterolithotomy

 

Explanation:

Given the clinical scenario with Rigler's triad (small bowel obstruction, pneumobilia, and ectopic gallstone) and the corresponding imaging findings, the most likely diagnosis is gallstone ileus. The optimal initial surgical management is enterolithotomy, which effectively relieves the intestinal obstruction by removing the impacted gallstone.


 

Effects and Complications of Gallstones:

 

Gallbladder

Common bile duct and pancreas

Small intestine
  • Acute cholecystitis
  • Chronic cholecystitis
  • Mucocele
  • Empyema
  • Gangrene
  • Perforation
  • Carcinoma gallbladder
  • CBD stones
  • Biliary obstruction (Jaundice)
  • Acute pancreatitis
  • Mirizzi syndrome

Gallstone ileus leading to intestinal obstruction

 

Gallstone Ileus

  • Acute cholecystitis→ erosion of inflamed tissues → Formation of a cholecystointestinal fistula→ Gallstone ileus
  • Small gallstones typically pass through the intestines, but stones 2–5 cm in size can become impacted, usually in the terminal ileum or at the ileocecal valve.

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Acute, intermittent, or chronic episodes of partial or complete gastrointestinal obstruction.
  • Signs of obstruction include dehydration, abdominal distension and tenderness, high-pitched bowel sounds, and obstructive jaundice.

Diagnosis:

  • Plain Abdominal Radiograph:
    • Partial or complete intestinal obstruction
    • Pneumobilia or contrast material in the biliary tree
    • Calcified gallstone with position changes on serial films (tumbling sign)
  • CT Scan:
    • Superior sensitivity (up to 93%)
    • Shows abnormal gallbladder with air, air-fluid level, or fluid accumulation with an irregular wall

Management:

  • Management of intestinal obstruction
  • Enterolithotomy: The most common surgical procedure
    • A longitudinal incision on the antimesenteric border proximal to the site of impaction
    • Gallstone is brought to a non-edematous bowel segment by gentle manipulation and extraction.
  • Cholecystoenteric fistula resection only if the patient is stable and there are residual gallstones that may cause infection or recurrent ileus

Cholecystectomy and fistula repair (Option A): While important, this is not the initial step due to the patient's unstable condition and intestinal obstruction.

Endoscopic removal of the gallstone (Option B): Not feasible for this condition due to the intestinal obstruction.

Conservative management with IV fluids and antibiotics (Option D): Not sufficient for resolving the mechanical obstruction.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of diabetes presents with severe right upper quadrant pain, fever, and jaundice. Imaging reveals gas within the gallbladder wall. Which of the following organisms is most likely to be the causative agent in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Clostridium perfringens

Explanation:
The patient is presenting with emphysematous cholecystitis, a severe form of acute cholecystitis characterized by the presence of gas in the gallbladder wall. This condition is often caused by gas-forming bacteria.

Clostridium perfringens is the most commonly implicated bacterium in this condition, especially in patients with underlying diabetes.

 

Causative Organisms of Emphysematous Cholecystitis:

  • Clostridium perfringens
  • Clostridium welchii
  • Escherichia coli
  • Klebsiella

questions.text: A 70-year-old female presents with vague right upper quadrant discomfort, but she is mostly asymptomatic. An abdominal X-ray reveals extensive calcification of the gallbladder wall. There is bluish appearance and brittle consistency of the gallbladder. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Porcelain gallbladder

 

Explanation:

The findings of extensive calcification of the gallbladder wall, along with the bluish appearance and brittle consistency, are characteristic features of a porcelain gallbladder.

Porcelain Gallbladder

Definition:

  • Also known as calcified gallbladder, characterized by extensive calcium encrustation in the gallbladder wall.

Characteristics:

  • Bluish appearance of the gallbladder.
  • Brittle consistency of the gallbladder wall.

Clinical Features:

  • Most patients are asymptomatic.
  • Increased risk of malignancy.

Diagnosis:

  • Incidental findings on abdominal X-ray or CT

 

Treatment: Early laparoscopic cholecystectomy is recommended due to the increased risk of malignancy.

 

Gallbladder carcinoma (Option A): While there is an increased risk of malignancy associated with porcelain gallbladder, the symptoms and imaging findings in this scenario point more directly to porcelain gallbladder rather than cancer itself, especially given that the patient is asymptomatic.

 

Cholesterolosis (Option B): This condition is characterized by lipid accumulation in the gallbladder mucosa and does not present with calcification of the gallbladder wall.

 

Acute cholecystitis (Option D): This would typically present with acute pain, fever, and signs of inflammation, which are not described in this scenario.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for gallbladder carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Smoking

 

Explanation:

While smoking is a risk factor for several cancers, it is not specifically recognized as a risk factor for gallbladder carcinoma.

Risk Factors For Carcinoma GB

Gallstones:
  • 90% of gallbladder carcinoma cases are associated with gallstones. (Option B)
  • The risk of developing carcinoma in gallstone disease is 7-10 times higher than in the general population.
  • Relative risk based on stone size:
    • Less than 2 cm: Lower risk
    • 2-3 cm: Relative risk of 2.5
    • More than 3 cm: Relative risk of 10 or more

Other Conditions:
  • Choledochal cyst
  • Anomalous pancreaticobiliary duct junction (20%)
  • Cholesteroses of the gallbladder
  • Gallbladder polyps (more than 1 cm in size, more than 3 in number, or adenomatous polyps)
  • Porcelain gallbladder (Option C): 25% risk of malignant transformation, with 90% being inoperable tumours

Infections and Inflammatory Conditions:
  • Chronic typhoid carriers
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Hepatitis B (Option D) and hepatitis C virus infections

Other factors:
  • Polypoid lesions (GB polyp)
  • Xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis
  • Nitrosamines
  • Carcinogens

questions.text: A 50 y/o woman undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy is found to have a structure that appears to have a spiral configuration. What is the most likely anatomical feature being observed?
questions.solution:
• Correct Answer: D) Valves of Heister

     

    Explanation:

  • The Valves of Heister are spiral mucosal folds within the cystic duct.
  • They help regulate the flow of bile and prevent excessive emptying of the gallbladder.
  • These folds are a key feature of the cystic duct and are noted during cholecystectomy.

The cystic duct serves as the conduit between the gallbladder, where bile is stored, and the common bile duct, which carries bile to the duodenum. The Sphincter of Lütkens is a muscular structure encircling the cystic duct which plays a role in regulating bile flow into and out of the gallbladder.

questions.text: A 45 y/o woman presents to the ER with severe right upper quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. She has a history of gallstones and is diagnosed with acute cholecystitis. During laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the surgeon encounters difficulty identifying the cystic artery due to inflammation. Which anatomical landmarks within Calot's triangle would be most helpful in locating the cystic artery?
questions.solution:
• Correct Answer: B) Cystic lymph node

     

    Explanation:

  • The cystic lymph node, or Lund’s node, is located within Calot's triangle.
  • It serves as an important landmark for identifying the cystic artery.
  • Inflammation or anatomical variations can obscure typical landmarks, making the cystic lymph node a valuable reference point during surgery.

 

 

Calot's triangle, also known as the cystohepatic triangle, is an important anatomical area during gallbladder surgery. The boundaries of Calot's triangle are defined by:

  • Cystic duct (lateral boundary)
  • Common hepatic duct (medial boundary)
  • The inferior surface of the liver (superior boundary)

The contents of Calot's triangle typically include the cystic artery, which supplies blood to the gallbladder, and the cystic lymph node (Lund’s node). Identification of these structures is crucial during a cholecystectomy to avoid accidental injury to the biliary or vascular systems.

Note: The term "hepatocystic triangle" is often used interchangeably with Calot's triangle. It emphasizes the inclusion of the liver's inferior surface as part of the boundaries, along with the cystic duct and the common hepatic duct.

questions.text: A 45 y/o patient presents with recurrent right upper quadrant pain and nausea. Imaging reveals a pathological outpouching in the infundibular region of the gallbladder containing multiple gallstones. What is this feature known as?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hartmann's pouch

 

Explanation:

Hartmann's pouch is a pathological outpouching in the infundibular region of the gallbladder, typically associated with the presence of gallstones. It results from adhesions forming between the cystic duct and the neck of the gallbladder.

 

CD- Cystic duct

HP- Hartmann’s pouch

Gb- Gall Bladder

 

 

 

Phrygian cap (Option A): is a benign congenital anatomical variant of the gallbladder, characterized by a fold at the fundus that creates a cap-like appearance. It does not involve the presence of gallstones.

 

A floating gallbladder (Option B) is a rare anatomical pathological variant where the gallbladder is not properly attached and can move within the abdominal cavity. It does not result in an outpouching containing stones.

 

Gallbladder carcinoma (Option D) is a malignant tumour of the gallbladder and does not match the patient’s imaging results of outpouching.

questions.text: Which layer of the gastric wall is considered the strongest?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Submucosa
 

Explanation:

The submucosa is rich in collagen and provides the strongest structural support among the gastric wall layers. It is the strongest layer.

 

 

Layers

Features

Serosa
  • Outermost layer
  • Covered by peritoneum

Muscularis Propria / Muscularis externa
  • Divided into
    • Outer longitudinal layer
    • Inner circular layer
  • Contains Auerbach Plexus

Submucosa
  • Collagen-rich connective tissue layer
  • Strongest
  • It contains a network of blood vessels, lymphatics, and Meissner Plexus

Mucosa

 

Has 3 layers

  • Surface epithelium - outermost layer in contact with the lumen
  • Lamina Propria - connective tissue layer
  • Muscularis Mucosa - rugae formation

questions.text: A 65 y/o female presents with a 3-month history of intermittent upper right quadrant pain, weight loss, and loss of appetite. She has jaundice and a palpable mass in the right upper quadrant. Laboratory tests reveal mild anaemia, leukocytosis, and elevated CA19-9 and carcinoembryonic antigen. USG suggests a gallbladder mass and a CT scan confirms the mass without distant metastases. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Percutaneous biopsy of the gallbladder mass

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Laparoscopic examination for staging

Explanation:

Given the patient's symptoms, physical findings, and elevated tumor markers, gallbladder cancer is highly suspected.

  • Although imaging studies have been done, accurate staging is crucial before deciding on a definitive treatment.
  • A laparoscopic examination will help to detect any peritoneal or liver metastases that could preclude surgical resection, thereby guiding the appropriate management plan.

 

Diagnosis and staging of Gallbladder cancer: 

  • Non-specific indicators:
    • Anemia
    • Leukocytosis
    • Slight increase in transaminases
  • Tumor markers:
    • Elevated CA19-9
    • Elevated carcinoembryonic antigen (in ~80% of patients)

Diagnostic Imaging:

  • Ultrasonography (USG): Initial diagnosis
  • CT Scans: Thorax, abdomen, and pelvis for confirmation and staging
  • MRI/MRCP: For accurate preoperative staging
  • PET Scans: To identify metastatic disease

Staging and Biopsy:

  • Preoperative Staging: Crucial to assess local disease extent and rule out distant metastases
  • Percutaneous Biopsy: Guided by radiological imaging for unresectable tumors
  • Laparoscopic Examination: Detects peritoneal or liver metastases that preclude surgery

Immediate laparoscopic cholecystectomy (Option A): This is generally considered if the diagnosis is benign or if it's a straightforward case of symptomatic gallbladder disease. Given the suspicion of malignancy (indicated by elevated tumor markers and imaging findings), it is crucial to staging the disease before proceeding with surgical intervention.

Percutaneous biopsy of the gallbladder mass (Option B): While this could be useful, gallbladder cancers are often difficult to biopsy percutaneously, and the risk of seeding the tumor or causing complications is a concern.

Referral for palliative chemotherapy (Option C): This should only be considered if there is confirmed advanced or metastatic cancer. In this case, there is no evidence of distant metastases from the CT scan.

questions.text: Which of the following surgeons is correctly matched with their pioneering laparoscopic procedure and year of achievement?

choices.text: Professor Erich Mühe - First video-assisted laparoscopic cholecystectomy in 1987
Dr. Philippe Mouret - First laparoscopic cholecystectomy in 1985
Dr. Kurt Semm - First laparoscopic appendicectomy in 1983
Professor Erich Mühe - First laparoscopic appendicectomy in 1983

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Dr. Kurt Semm - First laparoscopic appendectomy in 1983

Explanation:

Dr. Kurt Semm performed the first laparoscopic appendicectomy in 1983.

 

  • Professor Erich Mühe of Germany is acknowledged as the pioneer who performed the first laparoscopic cholecystectomy in 1985. (Options A & D ruled out)

 

  • Dr. Philippe Mouret performed the first video-assisted laparoscopic cholecystectomy in 1987. (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents with intermittent right upper quadrant pain and nausea. An ultrasound shows significant thickening of the gallbladder wall and hyperproliferation of the mucosa. Which of the following is NOT a USG finding in Adenomyomatosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Porcelain appearance

 

Explanation:

Porcelain appearance is usually seen as associated with calcifications of the gall bladder and not adenomyomatosis

Adenomyomatosis

Definition: A benign condition characterised by hyperplastic changes in the gallbladder wall, often associated with cholesterol stones.

Characteristics:

  • Hyperplastic Changes:
    • Overgrowth of the gallbladder mucosa.
    • Significant thickening of the muscle layer.
    • Deposition of cholesterol crystals in the deep Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses.

Diagnosis:

  • Ultrasound Findings:
    • Diamond ring sign. (Option A)
    • Comet tail artefacts. (Option B)
    • V-shaped artefacts. (Option C)

 

 

Treatment:

Symptomatic Patients with Gallstones: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male, with past h/o cholesterol stones, presents with intermittent right upper quadrant pain and occasional nausea.USG reveals the gallbladder mucosa has a coarse, granular appearance with small nodules and some larger polypoid formations. On performing laparoscopic cholecystectomy of this patient, the following appearance of the gall bladder was observed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cholesterolosis

 

Explanation:

These specific ultrasound findings and the specimen along with the association with cholesterol stones are characteristic of cholesterolosis (strawberry gallbladder).

 

Strawberry Gallbladder (Cholesterolosis)

Definition: Characterized by the accumulation of lipids (triglycerides, cholesterol precursors, and cholesterol esters) in the gallbladder mucosa.

Appearance:

  • Nodules <1 mm in diameter in about two-thirds of cases, giving the mucosa a coarse, granular look.
  • In the remaining one-third of cases, nodules are larger and polypoid (polypoid form).
  • Yellow lipid deposits on a hyperaemic mucosa background create the ‘strawberry gallbladder’ appearance
  • May be associated with cholesterol stones.

Management:

  • Laparoscopic cholecystectomy in symptomatic patients.

Acute cholecystitis (Option A): Typically presents with more acute symptoms, such as severe right upper quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis, without the specific ultrasound appearance described.

Porcelain gallbladder (Option B): Characterized by extensive calcium encrustation of the gallbladder wall, giving a bluish, brittle appearance, not mentioned in the scenario.

Gallbladder carcinoma (Option D): Typically associated with more serious symptoms and imaging findings of masses or irregular thickening, not specifically described in this scenario.

questions.text: A 65 y/o presents with jaundice, weight loss, and abdominal pain. O/E a palpable mass is noted in the right upper quadrant. Imaging studies reveal a mass involving the gallbladder, with signs of local invasion but no distant or lymph node metastasis. A biopsy confirms gallbladder carcinoma. Based on the TNM classification, which stage is most likely for this patient's tumour?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) T3 N0 M0

Explanation:

The patient's presentation of jaundice, weight loss, abdominal pain, and a palpable mass, along with imaging showing local invasion but no distant metastasis, suggests an advanced stage. According to the TNM classification:

  • T3: Tumor perforates the serosa and/or invades the liver or adjacent organs.
  • N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.
  • M0: No distant metastasis.

This corresponds to T3 N0 M0.

 

Category

Description
 

Tis

Carcinoma in situ

T1

Tumor invades lamina propria or muscle layer

T1a

Tumor invades lamina propria

T1b

Tumor invades muscle layer

T2

Tumor invades perimuscular connective tissue

T2a

Tumor does not extend to serosa

T2b

Tumor extends to serosa, but does not invade the liver

T3

Tumor perforates serosa and/or invades liver/adjacent organs

T4

Tumor invades main portal vein/hepatic artery/multiple extrahepatic organs
 

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis

N1

Metastases to 1-3 regional lymph nodes

N2

Metastases to >3 regional lymph nodes
 

M0

No distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis

This TNM classification assists in determining treatment approaches and provides prognostic information for gallbladder carcinoma.

questions.text: A 58 y/o presents with jaundice, weight loss, and upper right abdominal pain. Imaging studies including CT and MRI reveal a mass in the gallbladder with local invasion into the liver but no distant metastasis. The patient undergoes a laparoscopic examination confirming the staging. What is the most appropriate treatment approach for this patient?

choices.text: Radical en bloc resection of the gallbladder, liver wedge, and regional lymph nodes
No further treatment if the tumor is confined to the mucosa

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Radical en bloc resection of the gallbladder, liver wedge, and regional lymph nodes

Explanation:

For a patient with gallbladder cancer of T3 N0 M0 staging, radical en bloc resection is the most appropriate treatment approach. This involves the surgical removal of the gallbladder, the invaded portion of the liver, and potentially affected regional lymph nodes.

This approach aims to achieve clear margins and effectively treat the localized disease, offering the best chance for a cure in the absence of distant metastasis.

Staging Aims to:

  • Assess local disease.
  • Detects metastatic disease in the liver, peritoneum, lymphatics, or locations outside the abdomen.

 

Treatment Based on Stage:

If Gallbladder cancer is found incidentally on resection of gallbladder for gallstones, then:

  • If, early disease:
    • For disease confined to the mucosa, if negative cystic duct margin and no recurrence on imaging- No further treatment
  • For transmural disease- Radical en bloc resection of gallbladder fossa, liver wedge, and regional lymph nodes.
  • If, advanced Cancer:
    • Non-operative palliative care.
    • Endoscopic/percutaneous methods to relieve obstructive jaundice.
  • Adenocarcinoma:
    • Early-stage limited to mucosa:
  • No additional treatment is required if imaging shows no recurrence.
  • Beyond mucosa:
    • Extensive surgery involving gallbladder fossa, a portion of the liver, and nearby lymph nodes.

Endoscopic stenting to relieve jaundice (Option A): Given the cancer's local invasion into the liver, endoscopic stenting alone does not provide a treatment for the cancer itself.

Palliative chemotherapy (Option C): Typically used for cancers that are not amenable to surgical resection or have spread beyond the local area (distant metastasis).

No further treatment if the tumor is confined to the mucosa (Option D): Since local invasion into the liver is present, a more aggressive treatment approach is required.

questions.text: A 45-y/o female presents with symptomatic gallstones and is scheduled for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. During the procedure, the surgeon encounters difficulty due to unexpected anatomical variations. The right hepatic artery appears very tortuous and is located close to the cystic duct. What is the most likely anatomical anomaly encountered in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Moynihan Hump

Explanation:

  • Moynihan's hump, also known as the 'caterpillar turn,' describes a very tortuous common or right hepatic artery in front of the cystic duct's origin. This tortuosity often results in a short cystic artery, increasing the risk of arterial injury during cholecystectomy.
  • It is the most dangerous anomaly to be encountered during laparoscopic cholecystectomy as it can lead to heavy bleeding due to injury to the arteries.

Phrygian cap (Option A) is a congenital variant of the gallbladder characterized by a fold at the fundus that resembles a cap. It is a benign condition and is typically asymptomatic, with its appearance being consistent with a cap-like structure on ultrasound. It has no clinical significance and does not affect gallbladder function.

 

Floating gallbladder (Option C) refers to an abnormal positioning of the gallbladder within the abdominal cavity, often due to a lack of supporting attachments. This condition does not present as a cap-like fold on ultrasound.

 

Mirizzi syndrome (Option D) occurs when a gallstone migrates from the gallbladder and obstructs or compresses the common bile duct, often due to a stone in the lower end of the cystic duct ulcerating into the common bile duct.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, and fever. Imaging reveals a gallstone eroding less than one-third of the circumference of the common bile duct. What is the management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Partial cholecystectomy with choledochoplasty

 

Explanation:

This patient’s presentation matches the features of Type II Mirizzi syndrome, characterized by a gallstone eroding less than one-third of the circumference of the common bile duct (CBD) or common hepatic duct (CHD). Type II Mirizzi syndrome is managed by partial cholecystectomy with choledochoplasty.

 

Csendes classification:

 

Mirizzi’s Type

Features

Treatment

Type I

Extrinsic compression of the CBD/CHD by a large impacted stone in Hartmann's pouch;

  • IA- the presence of cystic duct
  • IB- is obliterated cystic duct

Subtotal/Partial cholecystectomy + ERCP stenting
(Option C ruled out)

Type II

The stone has eroded the CBD/CHD less than 1/3rd circumference of the CBD/CHD forming a fistula

Partial cholecystectomy with choledochoplasty

Type III

Involving up to 2/3rd of the circumference of CBD/ CHO

Partial cholecystectomy with choledochoplasty

Type IV

Cholecystocholedochal fistula (>2/3rd) involving the entire circumference of the CBD/CHD

Bilio-enteric anastomosis
(Option A ruled out)

TypeV

Cholecystocholedochal fistula with cholecystoenteric fistula without gallstone ileus (VA) or with

gallstone ileus (VB)

Bilio-enteric anastomosis


 

 

Percutaneous cholecystostomy (Option B): Typically a temporary measure for critically ill patients who cannot undergo immediate surgery

questions.text: A 70-year-old critically ill male in the ICU with sepsis and multiple organ failure presents with sudden onset of right upper quadrant pain, fever, and jaundice. Bedside ultrasonography shows a distended gallbladder with thickened walls and pericholecystic fluid but no gallstones. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:D) Percutaneous cholecystostomy

 

Explanation:

  • Given the clinical scenario and the USG findings, this patient is most likely suffering from Acalculous cholecystitis.
  • Percutaneous cholecystostomy is the most appropriate management for a critically ill, unstable patient with acalculous cholecystitis, as it provides effective drainage and infection control with minimal risk.

 

 

Treatment:

  1. Initial Management:
    • Early broad-spectrum antibiotics
    • Fluid resuscitation
  2. Definitive Treatment:
    • Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy: Most definitive treatment
      Safe even with severe acute inflammation if the patient is stable for surgery
  3. For Critically Ill, Unfit for Surgery Patients:
    • Percutaneous Cholecystostomy: Preferred treatment
      Approximately 90% improvement rate with a cholecystostomy tube
    • Interval Cholecystectomy: Can be considered after recovery, but not mandatory in the absence of gallstones or other gallbladder pathology

Laparoscopic cholecystectomy (Option A): Although this is the definitive treatment for cholecystitis, it is often too risky for critically ill, unstable patients due to the invasive nature of the procedure and the need for general anaesthesia.

Oral antibiotics and observation (Option B): This approach is insufficient for acalculous cholecystitis, which typically requires more aggressive intervention to manage the infection and decompress the gallbladder.

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) (Option C): While ERCP can be useful for managing bile duct stones and obstructions, it is not the standard treatment for acalculous cholecystitis, which involves inflammation of the gallbladder without gallstones.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with asymptomatic gallstones is being evaluated for prophylactic cholecystectomy. Which of the following is NOT typically considered an indication for prophylactic cholecystectomy?

choices.text: Presence of gallstones in the common bile duct

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Asymptomatic small gallbladder polyps

Explanation:

Small asymptomatic gallbladder polyps are generally not an indication for prophylactic cholecystectomy unless they are larger than 1 cm or have other risk factors for malignancy.

Prophylactic Cholecystectomy:

Prophylactic cholecystectomy involves the removal of the gallbladder in patients with gallstones who are asymptomatic. This procedure is considered when the potential risk of gallstone-related complications outweighs the surgical risks.

Specific situations warranting prophylactic cholecystectomy include:

  • Large Gallstones (Option A): Stones >3 cm have a higher likelihood of causing complications.
  • Choledocholithiasis (Option B): Gallstones in the common bile duct increase the risk of cholangitis and pancreatitis.
  • Chronic Hemolytic Conditions: Conditions like sickle cell disease and hereditary spherocytosis lead to pigment stone formation.
  • Gallbladder Polyps: Polyps >1 cm may become malignant, justifying prophylactic surgery.
  • Suspicion of Malignancy: Anomalous pancreatic ductal drainage may raise concern for cancer.
  • Porcelain Gallbladder: Calcified gallbladder walls are linked to a higher cancer risk.
  • High-Risk Ethnic Groups: Certain groups, such as Native Americans and people from northern India, have a higher incidence of gallbladder cancer associated with gallstones.
  • Transplant Patients: Prophylactic removal during transplantation can prevent future complications.
  • Bariatric Surgery (Option D): Concurrent gallbladder removal during bariatric surgery can reduce future risks.

Absolute contraindications for laparoscopic cholecystectomy include:

  • Sepsis: Risk of complications and need for extensive surgery.
  • Severe Bleeding Disorders: Difficult hemorrhage control.
  • Empyema of the gallbladder
  • Gangrenous cholecystitis
  • Portal hypertension
  • Peritonitis

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for dissolution therapy in gallstone management?

choices.text: Cholesterol stones which are typically radiolucent

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cholesterol stones that are typically radiolucent

Explanation:

Dissolution therapy is indicated for cholesterol stones, which are usually radiolucent, in patients with a functioning gallbladder and stones smaller than 1 cm.

Dissolution Therapy for Gallstones:

Mechanism:

  • Bile Acids: Medications like chenodeoxycholic acid (CDCA) and ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA) dissolve cholesterol gallstones by inhibiting cholesterol absorption from the gut and reducing cholesterol synthesis in the liver.
  • HMG-CoA Reductase Inhibition: These medications inhibit HMG-CoA reductase, a key enzyme in cholesterol production, and UDCA also hinders cholesterol absorption in the gastrointestinal tract.

Indications:

  • Functioning gallbladders
  • Cholesterol stones (typically radiolucent)
  • Single stone smaller than 1 cm
  • Elderly patients or those unfit for surgery

Contraindications:

  • Non-functioning gallbladder (Option A)
  • Stone larger than 1 cm (Option B)
  • Radio-opaque stones
  • Multiple stones (Option D)

Drawbacks:

  • Duration: Long-term medication use, often up to two years.
  • Efficacy: Inconsistent results and incomplete stone dissolution.
  • Cost: Expensive treatment.
  • Side Effects: Diarrhea, pruritus, and liver dysfunction.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with a history of diabetes and hypertension presents with right upper quadrant pain, fever, and elevated white blood cell count. According to the Tokyo Guidelines (2013/2018), what is the recommended treatment approach if the patient is diagnosed with Grade II acute cholecystitis and does not respond to antibiotic treatment and supportive care?

choices.text: Early gallbladder drainage followed by delayed/elective cholecystectomy.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Early gallbladder drainage followed by delayed/elective cholecystectomy.

 

Explanation:

  • Early gallbladder drainage is recommended for patients with Grade II acute cholecystitis with failure of response to antibiotics and general supportive care.
  • Delayed/elective cholecystectomy can be considered if the patient's performance status improves.

 

Acute cholecystitis grading:

Grade

Features

I

Mild Cholecystitis

II
  • Moderate Cholecystitis
  • Along with one of the following
    • Increased TLC (> 18,000/mm3)
    • Lasting > 72 hours
    • Palpable tender mass in RUQ of the abdomen
    • Biliary peritonitis, pericholecystic abscess, gangrenous cholecystitis, hepatic abscess, emphysematous cholecystitis

III

Severe Cholecystitis along with organ dysfunction

Tokyo Guidelines for Acute Cholecystitis Treatment (2013/2018)

1. Initial Non-Operative Treatment:

  • Nil by Mouth: Patients should not eat or drink until the pain subsides.
  • Intravenous Fluids: Administered until pain resolves.
  • Analgesics: Pain management.
  • Antibiotics: Broad-spectrum antibiotics effective against Gram-negative aerobes (e.g., cefazolin, cefuroxime, ciprofloxacin).

2. Definitive treatment:

Grade 1
  1. If fit for surgery- then do early laparoscopic cholecystectomy (Option A)
  2. If unfit:
  • Give antibiotics and supportive care
  • Observe
  • Then do delayed laparoscopic cholecystectomy

Grade 2

First antibiotics and supportive care are to be given

 
  1. If fit for surgery- then do early laparoscopic cholecystectomy
  2. If unfit:
  • GB drainage via tube cholecystectomy (tube compresses GB, hence causing a decrease in inflammation)
  • Then do delayed laparoscopic cholecystectomy (Option D)

Grade 3

First antibiotics and supportive care are to be given

 
  1. If no negative predictive factors and good performance status:
  • Then do early laparoscopic cholecystectomy
  1. If negative predictive factors are present
  • Then do Tube cholecystectomy/drainage first.
  • If the patient then shows
    • Good performance status- do delayed laparoscopic cholecystectomy
    • Poor performance status- observe

Timing of Surgery

  • Early Cholecystectomy: Performed within 5-7 days of symptom onset. Shortens hospital stays but has a higher conversion rate to open surgery.
  • Delayed Cholecystectomy: Surgery is delayed approximately 6 weeks if early cholecystectomy is not indicated.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain and fever. According to the Tokyo Guidelines, which combination of findings would confirm a diagnosis of acute cholecystitis?

choices.text: RUQ tenderness, elevated C-reactive protein, gallbladder wall thickening on USG.
Murphy's sign, fever, normal gallbladder wall on USG.
Palpable RUQ mass, normal white blood cell count, pericholecystic fluid on USG.
RUQ pain, elevated C-reactive protein, no imaging finding

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) RUQ tenderness, elevated C-reactive protein, gallbladder wall thickening on USG.

Explanation:

Above case meets all criteria (local sign, systemic sign, and characteristic imaging findings) for diagnosing acute cholecystitis.

Tokyo Guidelines for Acute Cholecystitis (2013/2018)

A) Local Signs of Inflammation:
  • Murphy's sign
  • Right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain/ tenderness, or a palpable mass.

B) Systemic Signs of Inflammation:
  • Fever
  • Elevated CRP
  • Elevated WBC

C) Imaging Findings:
  • Gallbladder wall thickening (>3 mm)
  • Pericholecystic fluid,
  • Ultrasonographic Murphy's sign.

Suspected acute cholecystitis is diagnosed when one local sign and one systemic sign of inflammation are present.

questions.text: An ultrasound image of the gallbladder is consistent with a congenital anatomical variant. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Phrygian cap
 

Explanation:

  • A Phrygian cap is a congenital variant of the gallbladder characterized by a fold at the fundus that resembles a cap.
  • It is a benign condition and is typically asymptomatic, with its appearance being consistent with a cap-like structure on ultrasound.
  • It has no pathological significance and does not affect gallbladder function.

 

 

 

A floating gallbladder (or gallbladder volvulus) (Option A) refers to abnormal positioning of the gallbladder within the abdominal cavity, often due to the presence of an abnormally long mesentery from the gallbladder to the liver bed, allowing it to float freely. This makes the gallbladder prone to volvulus. This condition does not present as a cap-like fold on ultrasound.

 

 

An accessory gallbladder (Option B) is a rare condition where an additional gallbladder exists alongside the normal one. It appears as a separate entity on imaging.

 

A gallbladder septum (Option D) is an abnormal partition within the gallbladder that can be mistaken for a Phrygian cap. It appears as a distinct partition.

questions.text:
A 45 y/o woman presents with severe right upper quadrant pain, fever, and nausea. She has a history of pain after fatty meals. O/E, she has right upper quadrant tenderness and a positive Murphy's sign. Lab tests show elevated alkaline phosphatase, bilirubin, transaminases, and leukocytosis.

Which investigation is best to confirm this patient’s diagnosis?

choices.text: CT Scan- Pericholecystic fluid, Impacted stones, gallbladder wall thickness
HIDA Scan- Non-visualization of the gallbladder

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) HIDA Scan- Nonvisualization of the gallbladder

 

Explanation:

The patient’s clinical features and lab results are suggestive of  acute cholecystitis.

  • HIDA Scan can be used to confirm (Gold standard) acute cholecystitis when ultrasound findings are inconclusive.
  • Non-visualization of the gallbladder on a HIDA scan indicates cystic duct obstruction, a key characteristic of acute cholecystitis thus making it a diagnostic feature.

 

 



 

ASPECT

INVESTIGATIONS

Investigation of Choice/ Initial Inv.

Ultrasound Abdomen:

  • Reveals the presence or absence of gallstones.
  • Posterior acoustic shadowing
  • Thickening of the gallbladder wall.
  • Sonographic Murphy's sign may be positive. ( tenderness in the abdomen due to pressure of the ultrasound probe over the visualized gallbladder) (Option A)

Gold Standard

Combination of clinical assessment, laboratory findings, and imaging results:

  • Patient history: This includes the presence of symptoms like right upper quadrant pain, fever, and a positive Murphy's sign on physical examination.
  • Laboratory tests: Findings might include mild elevations in alkaline phosphatase, bilirubin, transaminases, and leukocytosis.
  • Imaging: Ultrasound is the primary imaging tool, with HIDA scans and CT scans serving as supplementary tools when needed.

Other Investigations
  • HIDA/PIPIDA Radioisotope Study:
    • Useful for assessing gallbladder visualization.
    • Non-visualization of the gallbladder is diagnostic.
  • CT Scan Abdomen:
    • Identifies perforation, pericholecystic fluid, impacted stones, gallbladder wall thickness, and edema. (Option C)
    • Useful for detecting stones in the common bile duct (CBD).
  • Plain X-ray Abdomen:
    • Identifies radio-opaque gallstones (10% of cases). (Option B)
    • Rules out other causes of acute abdominal pain.
    • May show gas in the emphysematous gallbladder.
    • Useful to rule out duodenal ulcer perforation or peritonitis.
  • Liver Function Tests (LFT)
  • Total White Blood Cell Count (WBC Count)

questions.text:
A 45 y/o woman presents to the ER with severe right upper quadrant pain radiating to her back. She has a h/o gallstones. O/E, she exhibits tenderness in the right upper quadrant. An abdominal CT scan shows a characteristic triradiate pattern of gas within a gallstone.

 

Based on the CT findings, which of the following signs is most likely being described?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Mercedes-Benz sign

 

Explanation:

The "Mercedes Benz sign" and "seagull sign" are terms used to describe the appearance of specific types of radiopaque gallstones on plain radiographs and CT scans which have a radiolucent triradiate (Mercedes Benz sign) or biradiate (seagull sign) fissure in the centre containing nitrogen gas resembling the Mercedes-Benz logo.

 

 

Murphy sign (Option A) is a clinical finding elicited during a physical exam that indicates gallbladder inflammation and acute cholecystitis

While palpating the right upper quadrant, the examiner observes if the patient stops breathing voluntarily when the examiner exerts pressure under the right costal margin.

 

Mermaid sign (Option B) and Stellate scar sign (Option C) are not established radiological terms related to gallstones and can be seen in conditions like ‘fetal abnormalities’ and ‘renal cell carcinoma’ respectively.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes a characteristic of pigment stones?

choices.text: Black pigment stones are associated with bacterial β-glucuronidase activity in the bile duct.
Black pigment stones are associated with hemolysis.
Brown pigment stones are associated with excess bilirubin from hemolysis.
Black pigment stones are primarily composed of calcium bilirubinate and cholesterol.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Black pigment stones are associated with hemolysis.

 

Explanation:

Black pigment stones are associated with conditions causing hemolysis such as hereditary spherocytosis, and sickle cell disease, and are mainly composed of insoluble bilirubin pigment polymers.

 

 

Feature

Black Pigment Stones

Brown Pigment Stones

Composition

Insoluble bilirubin pigment polymer, calcium phosphate, calcium bicarbonate

Calcium bilirubinate, calcium palmitate, calcium stearate, cholesterol(Option D)

Location

Gallbladder

Bile ducts

Associated Conditions

Hemolysis (hereditary spherocytosis, sickle cell disease), cirrhosis

Bile stasis, infection, foreign bodies or parasites in the bile duct (Clonorchis sinensis, Ascaris lumbricoides)

Pathophysiology

Excess bilirubin from hemolysis precipitates in the gallbladder (Option C)

Bacterial β-glucuronidase deconjugates bilirubin in the bile duct; unconjugated bilirubin precipitates (Option A)

Image

questions.text: A 49-y/o woman presents with intermittent right upper quadrant pain that worsens after fatty meals. She has a history of Sickle cell disease and has been on total parenteral nutrition (TPN) for the past six months due to severe Crohn's disease post-ileal resection. She also gives a h/o OCP usage for 5 years. The patient underwent cholecystectomy which showed the following finding. Which of the following factors is least likely to contribute to the formation of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Ileal resection due to Crohn's disease

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Sickle cell disease

 

Explanation:

  • The image shows cholesterol gallstones. They are the most common type of gallstone in Europe and the U.S., accounting for 80% of cases. They form when cholesterol precipitates out of bile and combines with calcium salts, bile acids, bile pigments, and phospholipids. Cholesterol makes up between 50% and 99% of these gallstones.
  • Sickle cell disease is not associated with cholesterol Gallstones but rather with black pigment stones because these stones occur in hemolytic states.


 

Cholesterol Gallstones

Formation Mechanism

Cholesterol precipitates out into crystals when the concentration exceeds the solubility

Contributing Factors
  • Obesity
  • High-calorie diet
  • Oral contraceptives (Option D)
  • Ileal disease/resection (Option C)
  • Abnormal gallbladder emptying

Supersaturation of Bile

High cholesterol and lipid concentrations in bile secreted from the liver

The concentration of bile in the Gallbladder

Bile is concentrated through the absorption of water and sodium, increasing solutes and calcium

Crystal Nucleation

Cholesterol crystallizes when concentration exceeds solubility; accelerated by glycoproteins and immunoglobulins

Gallbladder Dysmotility

Increased stasis due to abnormal motility, promoting stone formation

Associated Conditions
  • Prolonged fasting
  • Total parenteral nutrition (Option A)
  • Vagotomy
  • Use of somatostatin analogues
